subject: US Chief of Staff Short states he is very confident a phase one trade deal with China will be signed before the end of the year
RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 8th November 2019: Week’s rally capped as US yet to decide on tariff roll backs
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities flat/up, Treasuries flat, Dollar up, Crude up.
  • REAR VIEW: Trump says roll backs aren’t decided, but doesn’t rule them out; Canadian jobs data disappoints; Mixed Michigan survey
  • NEXT-WEEK: SUN: Spanish General Election. MON: UK GDP (Prelim), Trade Balance, China Singles Day Holiday. TUE: UK Labour Market Report, German ZEW Survey, US NFIB Small Business Optimism. WED: EZ Industrial Production, US CPI, RBNZ Monetary Policy Decision, EIA STEO, BRICS Summit. THU: Chinese Industrial Production and Retail Sales, German GDP, EZ GDP & Employment (Flash), Banxico Monetary Policy Decision, US PPI, OPEC Monthly Oil Market Report. FRI: US Retail Sales and Industrial Production, IEA Monthly Oil Report, US Refunding Settlement. To download the full Week in Focus, please click here. To download the Central Bank Weekly, please click here. Previewing: Powell, RBNZ, Banxico; Reviewing: BOE, RBA.

* MARKETS WRAP: Markets moved sideways to end the week, experiencing some choppy tape action amid trade updates, albeit ranges were thin. There were further comments directly from President Trump that there was no decision yet made on rolling back tariffs which saw a kneejerk risk-off reaction across major asset classes. The greenback moved higher, with desks noting a catch up to yields given the week’s bear-steepening across the Treasury curve, where the 10-year yield now lies close to the 2.00% figure. The dollar strength weighed on its crosses, namely gold and Yen, and particularly CAD, which caught a double barrel blow from its disappointing October jobs data. Equity sectors were mixed, Disney (DIS) earnings supported the telecoms sector, whilst Duke (D) weighed on utilities; a late rally in oil prices (likely a factor of book squaring ahead of the weekend) failed to alleviate the energy sector from its losses, however.

* US/CHINA TRADE: US President Trump said himself on Friday that he has not yet agreed to roll back the tariffs on China, saying that China would like him to do so and wants to make a deal with the US; he added that the deal would be signed in the US (contrary to reports earlier in the week of it to be signed elsewhere). Politico reported a source citing Trump as saying he wants the deal signed this month. Other reports cited Trump as saying he would not “fully” roll back China tariffs. The White House spokesperson commented that the US is optimistic on a deal, saying if one is reached, then “some” tariffs could be lifted. These reports were in-fitting with previous sources reports, putting caution on the Chinese Commerce Ministry saying that the two countries had agreed to cancel tariffs on Thursday, nonetheless, the comment directly from the US President saw another bout of risk off in markets. By Trump saying he had not “YET” agreed to a tariff roll back, indicated that it was still certainly a possibility, a caveat which China Global Times Editor Hu Xijin highlighted. FBN’s Lawrence reported earlier in the session that White House Trade Advisor Navarro (noted policy hawk) said that the US is willing to postpone the December 15th tariffs and that would be it for a Phase One deal, so that the US has more wiggle room for negotiations in Phase 2 and Phase 3 deals. Although Navarro is considered a China hawk, his comments are not in complete contradiction with that of the Chinese side, who said the magnitude of cancellations can be negotiated and will depend on the Phase One content. Note that on Thursday the market sold off on reports that there was fierce opposition to tariff roll backs within the White House, with eyes on Navarro as a source of said opposition. Politico sources also reported Trump as saying he remained confident that some kind of deal gets done, but there is still some work needed and internal opponents of going soft on tariffs, adding that the White House made a conscious decision not to push back on the reports out of China as they viewed them as generally positive and favourable.

* CANADIAN JOBS DATA: Canadian employment data for the month of October disappointed on Friday; the number of jobs in the economy fell by -1.8k, against expectations for a 15.9k rise, driven by a 16.1k fall in full-time unemployment (vs a 14.3k rise in part-time employment). Unemployment printed in line with expectations at 5.5%, as did participation rate at 65.7%. Wage growth was a bright spot, with wages expanding at a solid 4.4%, slightly higher than the 4.25% rate of increase seen in September. Weakness was particularly strong in the Manufacturing and Construction industries, losing 23.1k and 21.3k jobs respectively, while Public Sector employment rose 28.7k, although “we have to consider that some of these jobs were related to temporary hiring because of the federal election” cautions ING, adding “there is a strong chance they will unwind”. The bank goes on to point out that private sector employment has now declined in four out of the last six months, which, despite strong wage growth and low unemployment, is a sign that the labour market could be peaking.

* UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN (NOV.): Headline figure came in at 95.7, missing the expected 95.9, but a rise from the prior 95.5. Capital Economics highlight that the figure is below its yearly highs, but well above the long-run average, which lends support to their view that consumption growth will continue to slow only gradually. The expectations component rose to 85.9 from 84.2, whilst beating the expected 84.9, whilst the conditions component dragged on the headline, falling to 110.9 from 113.2, undercutting the expectations for 112.5. Cap Eco note the rise in expectations is hardly surprising given the new ATHs in US equity bourses and trade developments, with the decline in conditions supporting the thesis of a slowdown in employment growth, but caveats that labour market conditions “clearly remain fairly strong.” The short-term inflation expectations remained unchanged at 2.5%, whilst the long-run figure rose to 2.4% from 2.3%, providing some market (and Fed) relief of deflationary pressures, albeit slim.

* WTI (Z9) SETTLED USD 0.09 HIGHER AT USD 57.24/BBL; BRENT (F0) SETTLED USD 0.22 HIGHER AT USD 62.51/BBL. Crude markets settled lower on Friday morning, as the market’s wider risk on rally seemingly paused for breath. As European traders arrived at their desks, crude prices came under pressure, with some desks pointing to mixed Chinese data; China’s crude imports rose 11.5% in October Y/Y but car sales shrank for a 16th consecutive month. Moreover, another decline in exports has “compounded fears of a Chinese economic slowdown”, says PVM. Regardless, after the US open, the direction reversed, and crude strengthened into the close settling higher; some desks suggested end-of-week book squaring as a possible explanation. In terms of price levels; WTI Dec’ 19 and Brent Jan’ 19 futures fell as low as USD 55.76/bbl and USD 60.66/bbl on the day, before both powered back into the green in lack of fundamental news heading to levels just shy of yesterday’s highs at USD 57.86/bbl and USD 62.87/bbl. Crude specific news flow again took a back seat; OPEC October output rose by 1.26 mbpd to 29.71 mbpd compared to September, according to a Platts survey. Elsewhere, Alberta’s Government said oil producers can drill from conventional wells without limits as of today, although curtailment orders remain in effect on existing producers' conventional oil wells. Separately, PBF’s Toledo refinery (170k BDP) is expecting to carry out maintenance on several units in Q1 2020. The Baker Hughes US rig count showed oil rigs -7 at 684, marking the third consecutive week of cuts, nat. gas rigs unchanged at 130 and total rigs -5 at 817.

* T-NOTE FUTURES (Z9) SETTLED UNCHANGED AT 128-12+. A lack of conviction in risk appetite was evident in the TPLEX which settled little changed. The T-Note was offered through the European session before reversing course in the latter end of the day, triggered by US President Trump saying he had not yet decided whether to roll back China tariffs. More broadly, looking at the week, the TPLEX has seen significant amount of selling, with yields at levels not seen since July, off their lows in late-August/early-September. Given the reported progress in US-China trade, Treasury refunding, ramped up corporate issuance and a Fed now (presumably) on pause, the selling pressure on the TPLEX is of little surprise in this first week of November.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 0.3% at 3093, NASDAQ-100 0.4% at 8256, Dow Jones 0% at 27681

* S&P 500 SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary 0%, Consumer Staples 0%, Energy -0.8%, Financials 0%, Health Care 0.8%, Industrials 0.2%, Information Technology 0.6%, Materials 0.4%, Telecommunication Services 0.4%, Utilities -0.4%

* STOCK SPECIFICS: McDonald’s (MCD) shares were supported on an upgrade to Buy from Neutral at Longbow; the analyst noted the Co. is in good hands following the appointment of its new CEO Chris Kempczinski, as he has played an integral role alongside the former CEO Easterbrook in driving company performance. AbbVie (ABBV) performed well; the Co. submitted a supplemental New Drug Application to the FDA for its Imbruvica for treatment of patients younger than 70 years old with small or chronic lymphocytic leukaemia. Separately, the Co. will price USD 28bln in supply next week for its Allergan (AGN) acquisition. Alibaba (BABA) made decent strides on reports that it is planning to launch its Hong Kong IPO in the last week of November, according to sources; the Co. hopes to raise USD 15bln in its offering. HP (HPQ) was under pressure on reports that its board is not convinced that a sale to Xerox (XRX) is the right move. DuPont de Nemours Inc (DD) moved lower in choppy trade, on reports that it is considering divesting is transportation business. Albemarle (ALB) was under pressure after being downgraded to Underweight from Neutral at JP Morgan, who noted the growth rate for global electric vehicles is slowing whilst lithium supply is picking up, leading its analysts to believe the Co.’s long term contracts are potentially to be renegotiated downwards. Elsewhere in notable downgrades, Tiffany & Co. (TIF) was pressured on a downgrade to hold from buy at Jefferies, citing limited scope for a third-party acquisition bid, although LVMH (MC FP) is reportedly willing to up its offer from USD 120/share. United Rentals (URI) performed well after being upgraded to Conviction buy at Goldman Sachs, while Cummins (CMI) was supported by an upgrade at Evercore ISI. Boeing (BA) and Southwest Airlines (LUV) saw pressure as it was announced LUV would be pushing back the flight schedule for BA’s 737 Max jet to March; from February previously. LUV also announced due to the delay it is unable to provide Q120 ASM guidance at this time. AstraZeneca (AZN) caught a bid during trade as its phase 3 Farxiga trial met its primary efficacy endpoint. Also of note, unconfirmed source reports noted takeover chatter for PayPal (PYPL), with Mastercard (MA) touted as a potential suitor with a USD 135/shr offer.

* EARNINGS: Disney (DIS) advanced on a solid EPS beat, whilst the entertainment Co. also announced a deal with Amazon (AMZN) for the Disney+ streaming service. Monster (MNST) was bid after reporting EPS and revenue beats whilst announcing a USD 500mln share repurchase programme. Booking Holdings (BKNG) posted a solid EPS beat and subsequently moved higher, with Expedia (EXPE) moving higher in tandem. On the flip side; Gap (GPS) fell after it’s cutting its outlook, while its CEO also stepped down. Moreover, Activision Blizzard (ATVI) was pressured after providing poor Q4 guidance. Utilities underperformed, despite the tentative feel to trade today, due to poor earnings from Duke Energy (DUK) and Ameren (AEE). Mettler Toledo (MTD) fell after its FY19 EPS view disappointed.

* FX WRAP:

USD

The Greenback is riding high against all bar a select few rival currencies on a mixture of positive/supportive factors, including an upbeat US non-manufacturing ISM survey, heightened prospects that Phase 1 of the trade deal with China could be in the offing and last but not least more pronounced UST yield curve steepening (of the bearish kind). Indeed, the DXY looks primed to extend its recovery from post-Fed and initial NFP lows beyond 98.000 through 98.300 and towards 98.500 if Fib resistance around 98.387 is breached (50% retracement of the drop from October/ytd peak to this month’s low to date).

YUAN

Overriding Dollar strength has pushed the Cnh and Cny back off best levels, but both remain around the psychological 7.0000 level after the PBoC set the onshore mid-point below the symbolic round number for the first time in more than 3 months overnight. However, the primary catalyst for the Renminbi rally has been the aforementioned constructive US-China trade developments and mutual agreement to simultaneously lift tariffs in stages and equal measures as each part of the multi-part accord is signed off. On that note, several question marks remain and following reports that some in the White House are still not on board with making concessions, late breaking headlines quoting President Trump claim he has not agreed to Chinese demands for the removal of all levies.

GBP

The Pound has retreated further from best levels despite more better than expected UK PMIs and a services headline print that rebounded to 50.0, with Cable down around weekly lows within a 1.2795-1.2950 range and Eur/Gbp vice-versa between 0.8660-0.8585 parameters. For once, political and Brexit uncertainty or bad news did not undermine/underpin Sterling as the election campaigns dominated domestic headlines and the only HoC vote of note was to choose a new Speaker. Instead, BoE ‘super’ Thursday turned out to be quite the opposite as 2 MPC voters dissented for a 25 bp ease, while the minutes and November MPR were both nuanced towards the dovish side. Note also, looming Moody’s ratings review could err on the side of an outlook downgrade.

AUD/NZD/CAD

Notwithstanding the seemingly constructive (on balance) US-China Phase 1 trade vibe noted above, the Aussie, Kiwi and Loonie are all ending the week weaker against their US counterpart, and at or near fresh wtd troughs. Aud/Usd is only just holding above 0.6850 after the RBA’s SOMP sounded somewhat less confident about a gentle economic turning point than the official post-policy meeting statement given a GDP forecast downgrade and discussion about non-standard stimulus. Meanwhile, Nzd/Usd has lost sight of 0.6400 in wake moderately sub-consensus NZ Q3 jobs data that might warrant some acknowledgment from the RBNZ next week, and in similar vein Usd/Cad has responded to Canada’s labour report revealing a surprise decline in headline payrolls that would have been even worse without a rise in temps and could unnerve the BoC after last week’s more downbeat outlook/assessment. Usd/Cad currently above 1.3200 vs circa 1.3115 at the other extreme.

EUR/CHF/JPY

Also flagging vs the Buck over the course of the week and ending close to worst levels on safe-haven unwinding and relative yield/Central Bank policy dynamics. Eur/Usd has recoiled from 1.1175 towards 1.1000 through a series of technical support levels and with the single currency perhaps factoring in some Spanish political premium ahead of the weekend election, while Usd/Chf is hovering just under 0.9975 vs almost 0.9850 after more dovish than usual SNB remarks from President Jordan and another increase in Swiss sight deposits. The BoJ has also been underlining its accommodation and Government reinforcing fiscal stimulus via PM Abe’s call for a supplementary budget, but the Yen retaining an element of underlying demand unlike Gold that has broken well below the Usd1500/oz threshold within a 109.48-108.20 approx band, perhaps on the premise that US-China trade hype is too euphoric or exuberant.

EM

Plenty of big moves, individual drivers and country specific impulses behind them, but of those the Rand, Real and Lira have grabbed their fair share of headlines if not more. Eskom power issues and reduced capacity have blighted the Zar that started the week brightly on post-Moody’s SA ratings relief, while the Brl has been literally undermined by the underwhelming interest in Brazil’s TOR auction of oil site blocks as some lots received no bids at all and the biggest one on offer only a few outside Petrobras that already owns 90% of the field. Elsewhere, softer than forecast Turkish CPI ramped up the pressure on the CBRT to reverse even more monetary tightening, but the Try was also rattled by more sabre-rattling from President Erdogan on the Syria front and complaints about the US not upholding its end of the peace pact. Moreover, the Foreign Ministry announced that the 2nd part of Russian S-400 missile system parts are still planned to arrive in Turkey next year.

US President Trump says he has not yet agreed to roll back tariffs on China; notes that China would like him to do so and China want him to make a trade deal - deal will be signed in the US
content: • Other newswires quote US President Trump as also saying that he won't "fully" roll back China tariffs and that China wants a partial tariff roll back.
reaction_details:
In an immediate reaction markets moved in a risk off:

  • E-Mini S&P Dec'19 futures fell from 3083 to 3073
  • USD/JPY fell from 109.30 to 109.10
  • USD/CNH rose from 6.9920 to 7.0040
  • Tnote Dec' 19 rose from 128-12 to 128-21

Although moves have now partially pared, as the next batch of headlines highlighted that US President Trump wants to sign the deal in the US
analysis_details:
• Yesterday morning, China's Commerce Ministry said that China and US had agreed to cancel existing tariffs in different phases, adding that the magnitude of tariff cancellations for Phase 1 deal can be negotiated. Moreover, China's MOFCOM said that if a Phase 1 trade deal is reached, both sides must cancel tariffs at the same time with the proportion based on agreement. The comments spurred risk on sentiment that prevailed for much of the day.
  • When the above headline is caveated with the headlines run by other newswires, suggesting that Trump was just saying he won't fully roll back tariffs as part of a Phase 1 deal, the picture actually appears to be little changed - we all ready knew that it was highly unlikely that all tariffs would be done away with as part of a Phase 1 deal; earlier, White House Trade Adviser Navarro said that the US is willing to postpone the December 15th tariffs and that is it for a Phase One deal, adding it is saving other tariffs to make sure we can negotiate Phase 2 and 3 with China. Although Navarro is considered a China hawk, his comments are not in complete contradiction with that of the Chinese side, who said the magnitude of cancellations can be negotiated and will depend on the phase one content.

subject: US Equity Movers: Monster Beverages (MNST) + 5.5%, Booking Holdings +5.3%, Disney (DIS) +3.8%, Albermarle (ALB) -5%, Gap (GPS) -5%, Activision Blizzard (ATVI) -1.3%
content:
Outperformers

  • Monster (MNST) higher on EPS & revenue beats, whilst announcing a USD 500mln share repurchase programme
  • Booking Holdings (BKNG) higher on an EPS beat, following previous competitor earnings (EXPE,TRIP) which were hit
  • Disney (DIS) higher on EPS beat, whilst also announcing a deal with Amazon (AMZN) for the Disney+ streaming service

Underperformers

  • Albermarle (ALB) lower on a downgrade to Underweight from Neutral at JP Morgan, noting the growth rate for global electric vehicles is slowing whilst lithium supply is picking up, leading the analyst to believe the co,’s long term contracts are potentially to be renegotiated downwards.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 8th November 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Major European bourses are cautious as the US/China trade front positivity abates slightly
  • In FX, DXY is firmer above 98.000, AUD subdued by SOMP, PBoC set USD/CNY fix below 7.00
  • Iranian Air Defences have reportedly shot down a drone on the edge of Persian Gulf, US defence Official said no reports of a US drone being shot down
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Labour Market Report; US University of Michigan Sentiment, Baker Hughes Rig Count; Fed’s Bostic, Williams, Daly, Brainard, Moody’s on UK

ASIA-PAC

Asian equities traded mixed as the region failed to sustain the momentum from the record levels on Wall St. where sentiment was initially boosted after US and China were said to have agreed to cancel existing tariffs in different phases, although some of the gains were later reversed on reports of fierce internal opposition from the US regarding the tariff rollbacks. ASX 200 (Unch.) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) were both lifted at the open although the sentiment in Australia gradually deteriorated amid hefty losses for gold miners and a growth forecast downgrade by the RBA, while Tokyo stocks also reversed course as a choppy currency overshadowed confirmation of an economic package and higher than expected Household Spending. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) were mixed as participants digested the latest trade figures which were better than expected but continued to show a contraction in both USD-denominated Exports and Imports, with the mainland bourses slightly favoured after MSCI raised China A-shares weighting in its Emerging Market Index to 4.10% from 2.55%. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower amid spillover selling from USTs and with prices reeling from the recent rise in yields, while weaker results in the 10yr inflation-indexed auction added to the uninspiring tone.

PBoC skipped open market operations and were net neutral on the week vs. Prev. CNY 590bln drain last week. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9945 vs. Exp. 6.9947 (Prev. 7.0008)

A Hong Kong student who fell from a car park while police and protesters were clashing last weekend passed away according to hospital officials, which reports suggested could likely further escalate tensions. (AFP)

Chinese Trade Balance (CNY)(Oct) 301.3B vs. Exp. 283.3B (Prev. 275.15B). (Newswires)

Chinese Exports (CNY)(Oct) Y/Y +2.1% vs. Exp. -1.4% (Prev. -0.7%)

Chinese Imports (CNY)(Oct) Y/Y -3.5% vs. Exp. -5.4% (Prev. -6.2%)

Chinese Trade Balance (USD)(Oct) 42.81B vs. Exp. 40.83B (Prev. 39.65B). (Newswires)

Chinese Exports (USD)(Oct) Y/Y -0.9% vs. Exp. -3.9% (Prev. -3.2%)

Chinese Imports (USD)(Oct) Y/Y-6.4% vs. Exp. -8.9% (Prev. -8.5%)

US 

Fed's Bostic (Non-Voter, Dovish) said the US economy is on solid footing and that monetary policy is accommodative, while he added further adjustments will be data dependent and that he is comfortable with standing pat to weigh economic data over the upcoming months. Furthermore, Bostic said he expects economic data released before end of the quarter to boost GDP growth and that he would not have supported the last rate cut if he had a vote on the policy committee. (Newswires)

US House Committees subpoenaed acting White House Chief of Staff Mulvaney in Trump impeachment inquiry. (Newswires)

UK/EU

SNP's Sturgeon if there is a hung parliamenrt, would seek to form a progressive alliance to block the Conservative party from Government. (Newswires)

ECB's Vasle says the ECB is determined to continue with its current policy until conditions improve. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State of Pomepo says the US wants more trade with Europe. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Iranian Air Defences have reportedly shot down drone over the port of Mahshahr, on the edge of Persian Gulf, reports Iranian Media according to Elint News. (Newswires)

US Defense Official says they have received no reports of a US drone being shot down, according to Elint News. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European bourses are cautious, as optimism regarding an imminent breakthrough on the US/China trade front abates slightly amid mixed reports. European indices, remain just off recent highs, following a strong start to the month of November. In terms of sector performance; defensives are on the front foot, with Utilities (+0.3%) and Telecoms (+0.1%) the only sectors in the green. Meanwhile, the more risk sensitive Tech (-0.6%), Consumer Discretionary (-0.8%) and Materials (-0.9%) sectors are the laggards. Financials (-0.6%) are also lower, with underperformance seen in Credit Agricole (-3.3%) and Natixis (-5.5%) following earnings. In terms of other notable individual movers; Richemont (-5.1%) were hit on an underwhelming earnings report, in which performance in Hong Kong was a dark spot; other luxury names were also pressured, including LVMH (-0.2%) and Kering (-0.7%). Elsewhere in earnings, a weak report from Fincantieri (-6.0%) saw its share price under pressure, while strong earnings from Leonardo (+0.5%) saw its shares advance. Delivery Hero (+0.8%) were boosted after being reiterated with a buy at Goldman Sachs.

FX

AUD/NZD/CAD - All on the back foot, but to varying degrees and not the weakest G10 links as the Greenback remains firm across the board. However, the Aussie has pulled back a bit further from 0.6900 in wake of the RBA’s latest Statement of Monetary Policy that revealed more detailed discussions on unconventional easing measures given that rates are relatively low and a GDP downgrade. The Kiwi is only holding up marginally better, but sub-0.6350 as the Aud/Nzd cross retains 1.0800+ statust, while the Loonie is on the defensive near 1.3200 against the backdrop of weaker oil prices and ahead of Canadian jobs and housing data.

SEK/NOK - The Scandi Crowns are on the retreat after posting decent gains on Thursday and threatening or testing key resistance levels vs the Euro, but failing to breach or sustain momentum. Eur/Sek is back above 10.6500 and Eur/Nok over 10.1000, with the Swedish Krona not gleaning any support from solid household consumption or news that former SEB Chief Economist Bremen will become a Riksbank Deputy Governor and likely back a December repo rate hike.

GBP/EUR/CHF/JPY - Narrowly mixed vs the Dollar, as the DXY inches a tad further above 98.000 to notch a fractional new post-FOMC high (98.246), but extremely or even excruciatingly rangebound amidst a paucity of independent factors/drivers. Indeed, Cable is trapped within a 1.2825-1.2796 band awaiting Moody’s UK ratings review after hours and Eur/Usd is meandering between 1.3037-28, while Usd/Chf and Usd/Jpy pivot 0.9950 and 109.25 respectively.

EM - The Rand remains on a roller-coaster, but still hampered by the ongoing Eskom power issues that is keeping Usd/Zar anchored around 14.8000, albeit with the broad Buck strength also impacting.

RBA Statement on Monetary Policy noted the board is prepared to ease policy further if required and that the pause in November allows time to assess effects of past easing and global events. RBA added the board is mindful rates are very low, that further cuts bring closer other policy options, and is aware more easing could convey overly negative view of the economy. Furthermore, RBA stated the Australian economy is gradually coming out of a soft patch and that global financial markets appear to have passed a trough of pessimism, while it lowered GDP growth forecast for December 2019 to 2.25% (Prev. 2.50%) but maintained December 2020 growth forecast at 2.75% and kept underlying inflation forecasts unchanged. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

Hardly any deviation beyond earlier ranges, but Gilts remain relatively depressed and just off a minor new Liffe low (131.05, -20 ticks vs +4 ticks at one stage) and Italian bonds are also underperforming Eurozone peers near the base of 141.60-142.56 parameters after the BTP exchange auction. However, Bunds and US Treasuries are still maintaining an underlying bid after Thursday’s rout and into the weekend that is 3 days long across the Atlantic due to Veterans Day, awaiting the preliminary Michigan sentiment survey for November, September wholesale inventories and sales plus more Fed speak.

COMMODITIES                                      

Energy markets remain subdued with WTI and Brent futures below the 56.50/bbl and 61.50/bbl marks respectively with lack of immediate fundamental catalysts at the time. In terms of technicals, Brent took out its 100 DMA to the downside (61.60/bbl) ahead of the 61.0/bbl psychological level with its 50 DMA seen at 60.93/bbl, whilst WTI sees support at 56/bbl which also coincides with its 100 DMA. Some cite recent downside in the complex to lower probably of deeper OPEC+ cuts in December given the seemingly improving US-China trade environment. Further, sources earlier in the week noted of hesitation from Saudi Arabia and Russia to reduce output. Participants may also eye geopolitical events after reports that Iranian Air Defences have shot down drone over the port of Mahshahr, on the edge of Persian Gulf, although it is not clear to whom the drone belongs to. Turning to metals, gold prices remain modestly subdued with markets on standby for the latest in the US-Sino saga with the yellow metal below its 100 DMA (1476.90/oz). Finally, Copper prices are drifting lower towards the 2.7/lb level amid the cautious risk sentiment, again on the lookout for the latest trade headlines.

subject: Riksbank names Anna Breman as its new Deputy Governor; Skingsley has been appointed as First Deputy Governor
analysis_details:
• Riksbank's Breman will start at the Riksbank 1 December and will be a voting member of the Executive Board at the monetary policy meeting 18 December (announcement 19 December).
  • "It is difficult to categorise Breman as for her monetary policy stance. The best guess is that she will follow the majority" says Nordea. "Thus," adds the bank "as the majority (Governor Ingves, Ohlsson and Skingsley) is for lifting rates, this is if anything hawkish as it makes a rate hike in December more likely."

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

8th November 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equities traded mixed as the region failed to sustain the momentum from the record levels on Wall St. where sentiment was initially boosted after US and China were said to have agreed to cancel existing tariffs in different phases, although some of the gains were later reversed on reports of fierce internal opposition from the US regarding the tariff rollbacks. ASX 200 (Unch.) and Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) were both lifted at the open although the sentiment in Australia gradually deteriorated amid hefty losses for gold miners and a growth forecast downgrade by the RBA, while Tokyo stocks also reversed course as a choppy currency overshadowed confirmation of an economic package and higher than expected Household Spending. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) were mixed as participants digested the latest trade figures which were better than expected but continued to show a contraction in both USD-denominated Exports and Imports, with the mainland bourses slightly favoured after MSCI raised China A-shares weighting in its Emerging Market Index to 4.10% from 2.55%.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 8th November 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian bourses traded mixed as the region failed to sustain the momentum from the record levels on Wall St
  • US and China sources noted that both sides want to have a Phase 1 trade deal down on paper by the end of next week
  • However, source reports stated the US plan to roll back China tariffs faces fierce internal opposition, no final decision has been made
  • Chinese trade figures topped estimates but continued to show a contraction in both USD-denominated exports and imports
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German Imports, Exports, Trade Balance; French Industrial Output; Canadian Labour Market Report; US University of Michigan Sentiment, Baker Hughes Rig Count; Fed’s Bostic, Williams, Daly, Brainard; Norges Bank Deputy Governor Matsen, Moody’s on UK

TRADE

US and China trade sources from both sides said they are still negotiating using the APEC timeframe and that both want to have a Phase 1 deal down on paper by the end of next week. (Fox Business News/Twitter)

 

NEC Director Kudlow said there will be tariff concessions if there is a Phase 1 deal. Furthermore, there were also separate comments from a US government spokesperson that the first China trade deal would include a tariff roll back and a White House aide also noted they very optimistic a deal with China will be reached soon. (Newswires)

Source reports stated the US plan to roll back China tariffs faces fierce internal opposition where no final decision has yet been made, while a US source also stated there are no plans to roll back any tariffs in exchange for phase one and that Chinese officials are trying to renegotiate the deal to their advantage. In related news, sources stated that China wants all tariffs rolled back as phases of the trade deals are completed, while the US has offered to roll back some tariffs but wants to keep a majority in place until the Chinese reach certain milestones after the full trade deal is completed. (Newswires/WSJ/Fox Business News)

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equities traded mixed as the region failed to sustain the momentum from the record levels on Wall St. where sentiment was initially boosted after US and China were said to have agreed to cancel existing tariffs in different phases, although some of the gains were later reversed on reports of fierce internal opposition from the US regarding the tariff rollbacks. ASX 200 (Unch.) and Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) were both lifted at the open although the sentiment in Australia gradually deteriorated amid hefty losses for gold miners and a growth forecast downgrade by the RBA, while Tokyo stocks also reversed course as a choppy currency overshadowed confirmation of an economic package and higher than expected Household Spending. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) were mixed as participants digested the latest trade figures which were better than expected but continued to show a contraction in both USD-denominated Exports and Imports, with the mainland bourses slightly favoured after MSCI raised China A-shares weighting in its Emerging Market Index to 4.10% from 2.55%. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower amid spillover selling from USTs and with prices reeling from the recent rise in yields, while weaker results in the 10yr inflation-indexed auction added to the uninspiring tone.

PBoC skipped open market operations and were net neutral on the week vs. Prev. CNY 590bln drain last week. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9945 vs. Exp. 6.9947 (Prev. 7.0008)

A Hong Kong student who fell from a car park while police and protesters were clashing last weekend passed away according to hospital officials, which reports suggested could likely further escalate tensions. (AFP)

 

  • Chinese Trade Balance (CNY)(Oct) 301.3B vs. Exp. 283.3B (Prev. 275.15B). (Newswires)
  • Chinese Exports (CNY)(Oct) Y/Y +2.1% vs. Exp. -1.4% (Prev. -0.7%)
  • Chinese Imports (CNY)(Oct) Y/Y -3.5% vs. Exp. -5.4% (Prev. -6.2%)
  • Chinese Trade Balance (USD)(Oct) 42.81B vs. Exp. 40.83B (Prev. 39.65B). (Newswires)
  • Chinese Exports (USD)(Oct) Y/Y -0.9% vs. Exp. -3.9% (Prev. -3.2%)
  • Chinese Imports (USD)(Oct) Y/Y-6.4% vs. Exp. -8.9% (Prev. -8.5%)

UK/EU

EU Commission President Juncker said he doesn't think that US President Trump will implement auto tariffs on the EU. (Newswires)

 

FX

In FX markets, the DXY remained firm and held above the 98.00 level as a result of the improving US-China trade climate and lacklustre trade in its major counterparts with EUR/USD stuck around 1.1050, while GBP/USD briefly attempted a breakdown of support at 1.2800 following the dovish BoE meeting where the MPC kept rates unchanged at 0.75% as expected but with surprise dissent as Haskel and Saunders opted for a 25bps reduction. Elsewhere, USD/JPY traded choppy in reflection of the wavering overnight risk tone and antipodeans were subdued with AUD/USD mildly pressured after the RBA Monetary Policy Statement reiterated a willingness to ease policy further if required and lowered the year-end GDP growth forecast, but with downside stemmed by the recent CNY strength in which the PBoC set the reference rate firmer than 7.0000 against the greenback for the first time in over 3 months.

RBA Statement on Monetary Policy noted the board is prepared to ease policy further if required and that the pause in November allows time to assess effects of past easing and global events. RBA added the board is mindful rates are very low, that further cuts bring closer other policy options, and is aware more easing could convey overly negative view of the economy. Furthermore, RBA stated the Australian economy is gradually coming out of a soft patch and that global financial markets appear to have passed a trough of pessimism, while it lowered GDP growth forecast for December 2019 to 2.25% (Prev. 2.50%) but maintained December 2020 growth forecast at 2.75% and kept underlying inflation forecasts unchanged. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were uninspiring in which WTI crude futures retreated below the USD 57.00/bbl level with overnight price action at the whim of the conflicting trade news, as the prior day’s advances that were fuelled by the positive US-China trade developments, later stalled on reports that tariff rollback plans face fierce opposition from within the US. Elsewhere, gold remained subdued on the continued USD strength but with losses stemmed after having recently found support at the October low around USD 1460/oz, while copper prices pulled back as the risk appetite gradually waned overnight on the conflicting trade rhetoric.

 

US

The TPLEX continued its march lower on Thursday, following some reprieve on Wednesday, as reports confirmed the US and China were moving to both remove tariffs on each other. The US sold 19bln in 30-year bonds tailing the 2.424% WI by 0.6bps, whilst being covered by 2.23x, in line with the six-auction average; the takedown was impressive, however, with dealers taking a record low share of 20.7%, directs took an impressive 20.5%, whilst indirects took 58.8%, in line with their average. However, although an impressive 30-year auction, it did little to change the dial on the sell-off in the debt complex. By settlement the US Treasury curve had re-steepened from Wednesday, with the 2s/10s just over 3bps wider, with the 2-year yield just over 7bps higher itself. T-note futures (Z9) settled 30 ticks lower at 128-12+.

Fed's Bostic (Non-Voter, Dovish) said the US economy is on solid footing and that monetary policy is accommodative, while he added further adjustments will be data dependent and that he is comfortable with standing pat to weigh economic data over the upcoming months. Furthermore, Bostic said he expects economic data released before end of the quarter to boost GDP growth and that he would not have supported the last rate cut if he had a vote on the policy committee. (Newswires)

US House Committees subpoenaed acting White House Chief of Staff Mulvaney in Trump impeachment inquiry. (Newswires)

content:

Other News 

MSCI said China A-shares weighting in MSCI Emerging Market Index will increase to 4.1% from 2.55%. (Newswires)

Hang Seng Index will announce results of its index review today. (Newswires)

 

Trade

US government spokesperson said the first China trade deal would include a tariff roll back, while China MOFCOM also stated that China and US have agreed to cancel existing tariffs in different phases and that negotiators are still trying to reach an interim deal. MOFCOM added that the magnitude of tariff cancellations for Phase 1 deal can be negotiated and that if a Phase 1 trade deal is reached, both sides must cancel tariffs at the same time with the proportion based on agreement. (Newswires/SCMP)

US is said to still be targeting next week as a timeline to sign on a phase 1 deal according to CNBC's Tausche, while FBN's Lawrence also stated that US and China trade sources from both sides say they are still negotiating using the APEC timeframe and that both want to have a Phase 1 deal down on paper by the end of next week. (Twitter)

There were later reports that the US plan to roll back China tariffs faces fierce internal opposition where no final decision has yet been made, while other sources stated that China wants all tariffs rolled back as phases of the trade deals are completed and that the US offered to roll back some tariffs but want to keep majority in place until the Chinese reach certain milestones after the full trade deal is completed. Furthermore, NEC Director Kudlow commented there will be tariff concessions if there is a Phase 1 deal. (Newswires/Fox/Twitter)

White House aide said they are very optimistic a deal with China will be reached soon. (Newswires)

China's Global Times Editor Hu Xijin said that the attitude of the Chinese side is clear that the two sides must simultaneously and proportionally remove the existing additional tariffs in order to reach phase 1 deal. Furthermore, Hu added that this is a realistic way to de-escalate the trade war and hopes it is also attitude of the US side. (Twitter)

China's Global Times tweeted China will accelerate the opening-up of the financial industry, lift all restrictions from the scope of business for foreign banks, securities firms and fund management firms. (Newswires)

China are considering the removal of restrictions on poultry imports for the US, according to Chinese press. (Xinhua)

  • Board is mindful rates are very low and further cuts bring closer other policy options.
  • Aware more easing could convey overly negative view of the economy.
  • Australian economy is gradually coming out of a soft patch and global financial markets appear to have passed a trough of pessimism.
  • Lowers GDP growth forecast for December 2019 to 2.25% (Prev. 2.50%) and December 2020 forecast maintained at 2.75%, while December 2021 forecast at 3%.
  • Maintains forecast on underlying inflation for December 2019 at 1.50%, December 2020 at 1.75% and sees December 2021 at 2.00%.
reaction_details: - AUD/USD saw a muted reaction although gradually fell by 8 pips to 0.6892 from 0.6900 in the minute after the release.
